snippet.textDisplay:
AJ made no excuses after he lost. He took defeat like a man and a first class professional.

Ruiz made excuse, after excuse, like a pathetic unprofessional little boy.

The contrast in their professionalism could not be more stark.

Congrats Anthony on a excellent boxing performance. You did great.
snippet.textOriginal:
AJ made no excuses after he lost. He took defeat like a man and a first class professional.

Ruiz made excuse, after excuse, like a pathetic unprofessional little boy.

The contrast in their professionalism could not be more stark.

Congrats Anthony on a excellent boxing performance. You did great.

snippet.textDisplay:
Rogan “What is your nutrition strategy?”

Ruiz “sandwiches”

Rogan “sandwiches???”

Ruiz “Yeah, I just had one”

Who wants to pay to watch someone fight who admits he can’t be bothered to train or eat properly? This man has already extracted more money from the paying public than most working class people earn in a lifetime. Top fighters get top money because of sacrifice, discipline and talent. Ruiz has talent in abundance........
snippet.textOriginal:

Ruiz “sandwiches”

snippet.textDisplay: Aj did what he needed too to win against an awkward fighter with fast hands.. there was no way he was going to stand and trade when there was so much at stake so he boxed for 12 rounds and showed unbelievable skill and footwork and worked behind the jab. Ruiz is no pushover but aj made him look silly. Ruiz trained for this fight and didn't bother about cutting weight because he's a smaller guy and thought aj would come like a raging bull but he didnt, he displayed skill and it was a masterpiece. And when he fights wilder which he will he'll probably use the same methods and stay out of the way of that power but thats all wilder has, punch power. Most of his fights that ive seen he is so lacking technically and just waits like a cobra cos he knows when he strikes they usually stay down so avoid that and its another win for joshua.
snippet.textOriginal: Aj did what he needed too to win against an awkward fighter with fast hands.. there was no way he was going to stand and trade when there was so much at stake so he boxed for 12 rounds and showed unbelievable skill and footwork and worked behind the jab. Ruiz trained for this fight and didn't bother about cutting weight because he's a smaller guy and thought aj would come like a raging bull but he didnt, he displayed skill and it was a masterpiece. snippet.textDisplay:
Ruiz didnt blame the ref or the venue or an injury.. He blamed himself for getting too fat.. Its honest. He was too fat. All the fight pundits said it- except freddie roach who said (when andy was losing weight) that andy looks better when hes heavy.maybe that got into his head.. Who knows?

Anyhow, the reality is boxing science won on the night. The guy with the longer reach kept the other at distance and jabbed their way to victory in a complete shut out

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm really dissatisfied with Ruiz performance and preparation for this fight.
All he had to do was to stay committed to the camp not friends, cars and food.
He knew this was his one shot for greatness but he got complacent from the first win.

For me, he wont be remembered as a GOAT.

I was a Ruiz fan

I'm really dissatisfied with Ruiz performance and preparation for this fight.

He knew this was his one shot for greatness but he got complacent from the first win. 

For me, he wont be remembered as a GOAT. 

I was a Ruiz fan

snippet.textDisplay: So what is Johnny saying ? It's 'proper BS' that Ruiz let himself go, but he 'just didn't take on the responsibilities that come with being champion', i.e. application and obsessive challenger mentality... you can't seriously claim the guy is lying and then insult him for precisely what you just accused him of lying about - maybe it's just contradictory and confused in the way it's conveyed, and I've misunderstood it, but it seems like a surefire double standard to me where the 'not mentally ready' excuses only applied to AJ in the first fight and have since expired completely - the scales. don't. lie.
snippet.textOriginal: So what is Johnny saying ? snippet.textDisplay:
Ruiz never boxed brilliantly to win


AJ boxed poorly and got very unlucky having his central nervous system so heavily affected by a lucky punch from Ruiz.

I look at the science of sport and there's no way Ruiz planned that punch. Its simply too inconsistent to be used as a tactic.
He got lucky, he knows he got lucky, and he knew there was no way it was happening again so he made the most of his dollars and made more in a rematch to boot.
He left the equasion being the first ever Mexican heavyweight world champion, a legend in his own right as a result, and a very wealthy man who never needs to work again as long as he uses his head.
He did well out of this.

But the better boxer prevailed.
snippet.textOriginal:
Ruiz never boxed brilliantly to win


AJ boxed poorly and got very unlucky having his central nervous system so heavily affected by a lucky punch from Ruiz.

I look at the science of sport and there's no way Ruiz planned that punch. Its simply too inconsistent to be used as a tactic.
He got lucky, he _knows_ he got lucky, and he *knew* there was no way it was happening again so he made the most of his dollars and made more in a rematch to boot.
He left the equasion being the first ever Mexican heavyweight world champion, a legend in his own right as a result, and a very wealthy man who never needs to work again as long as he uses his head.
He did well out of this.

But the better boxer prevailed.

snippet.textDisplay:
Wasn't the weight, had nothing to do with it. He weight 283 - hat, gym pants, shoes, socks, = 173 lbs. AJ ran the whole fight too smart to exchange because he would have got KO'd again. AJ conned him in and they touched gloves through out way to friendly. AJ conned Ruiz out of his title and Andy just chased him around for 12 rds like a dog without changing up his tactics. What he should have done was just step back wag his arms like a chicken to mimic him and then refuse from that point on to follow him around and wave motion his hands to AJ to c'mon and fight. The fans paid for to see a fight not a runner running away from a fight!!! All he had to do was change his tactic to back up and moving laterally and then when AJ reaches in to come in and fight slip inside and fight, and forget about being conned into chasing AJ the runner running around the ring, the crowd would force AJ to move forward to engage and fight or he would be belittled if he would not. Andy was their to fight, AJ was there to run. Simple tactics would win the fight. The weight was not the problem not worth mentioning except looking for an excuse, and would actually help him KNOCK AJ out!!!

Problem was neither he nor his trainer had the knowledge of what to do. Near the end of 12th round Andy frustrated motioned to AJ to come and fight, about 9 rounds too late. No one or no rules state that you have to like a fool follow and chase someone around the ring, for 12 rounds get shut out and lose the fight. Don't be stupid, don't make any excuse like your weight, change your tactic when it was obvious after 3 rounds it would never work. No one is going to pay a dime for the rematch, it was the most boring championship ever, and Ruiz was conned out of being Champion by a con artist runner. Whys are you so friendly to Joshua he just stole millions of your future earnings from your family!!! No one to blame but himself and his trainers and although I hate runners, you have to give AJ credit for conning Ruiz and his whole camp for being stupid enough to hand the championship back back over to AJ and without a fight!!!!

Andy was their to fight, AJ was there to run. Simple tactics would win the fight. The weight was not the problem not worth mentioning except looking for an excuse, and  would actually help him KNOCK AJ out!!! 

Problem was neither he nor his trainer had the knowledge of what to do. Near  the end of 12th round Andy frustrated motioned to AJ to come and fight, about 9 rounds too late. snippet.textDisplay: For all you saying that Joshua humbled himself, bla bla, and did not make an excuse after his loss, go back and review. For the first fight, he did make excuses for the day of the fight, he did not explain what went wrong during training, he did not talk about having lack of preparation, except only his team talking about the change of opponent and having the amount of time given to prepare and so on. His team made excuses and then all sorts of rumours indicating excuses originating from his team were made. Joshua spoke about the day of the fight using a sort of philosophical expression and semantic play (they were plain excuses), and as the months passed he would give a different meaning to previous statements made in order to fix it (diplomatic).  So, what difference does it make now, he prepared well to win by points, and he plans to move on and try to avoid getting entangled in real fights.
snippet.textOriginal: For all you saying that Joshua humbled himself, bla bla, and did not make an excuse after his loss, go back and review. Joshua spoke about the day of the fight using a sort of philosophical expression and semantic play (they were plain excuses), and as the months passed he would give a different meaning to previous statements made in order to fix it (diplomatic).  So, what difference does it make now, he prepared well to win by points, and he plans to move on and try to avoid getting entangled in real fights.

snippet.textDisplay: The ignorance of people not being able to understand or distinguish between context and literal expression. Ruiz is being asked by media in so many different ways: what went wrong? There is a different between making an excuse and explaining what went wrong to the way it is asked. Ruiz's only error is trying to satisfy the same question asked in so many different ways. The obvious is, and everyone knows this, Ruiz got heavier and looked slower, while Joshua became faster and better. In that, it is quite clear that one did not work on the game plan while the other did worked on the game plan. Ruiz stated that Joshua was better this time, he was the better fighter on that day. Ruiz is not making excuses for his loss to a better Joshua on that day. He is constantly explaining what happened in the run up to the fight, admitting he didn't follow the game plan during training, what is wrong with that? nothing. Give him time to assimilate and stop asking him questions, and stop adding more into what he has said. Ruiz knows that he has to look within himself and play it right.

snippet.textDisplay: Man, funny how when AJ gave a TON of excuses for losing first fight (I got knocked out sparring, concussed, anxiety attack at the tunnel before fight, blah blah blah) it was taken as an "ok, thats must of been why he lost." So what is the difference when Ruiz is just brutally honest and said he messed up preparing for the 2nd fight? C'mon now Nelson; you sound like a double standard bafoon with "that's bullshit" stuff. Keep it 100 pro, and give him the rematch! Its not like AJ won by knockout or anything, he jabbed at distance and RAN.
